area_name: Chalk Creek Boulder aka Boulder of Sorrow

content.description: Start about 10 feet to the right of the ramp route. Reach up to a left-facing sidepull. The first move off the ground is wicked. Switching to the right-facing corner a bit higher is cruxy also. Finish up and left.

On the west side of this boulder, sit start on the arete to the right 1ft. of prominent dihedral (V3)

Sorrowful Journey

. Go up rail then right to crimp, to right handhold then to good holds up top.  Big jug in dihedral is off! just before you go right.
Start at the right hand side of the slab. Traverse the groove up and to the left. Top out on the obvious rail.
content.location: Right hand side of the slab, closest to the trail.

content.description:
Start by doing

Switching Corners

. Finish by heading up and right to a crimp in the seam. The 1st ascent was done after TR rehearsal and brushing. I had 2 pads.

climbs.name: Little Monkey Traverse
climbs.fa: ? RD, but I'm sure BV climbers predate me

content.description:
Traverse on the right side of the boulder, starting from the same place as

Lie Back on Crack

. Move across to the left without using the tree. (The tree section is probably the crux). The finish is on the rails on the left hand side without using the top of the boulder. As it's not on the website yet, we named it LMT, but maybe some locals have it penciled in already under another name?
content.protection: No pro needed, but a pad is always useful!
content.location: The start is an obvious step-up on the right, and the finish is a top-out on the smaller of the ledges.

content.description: Good lie back up the right side of the boulder. On a Rail.
Climb the right side of the slab WITHOUT the arete.  Very good slab problem.
content.location: Front side of the boulder (the slabby part, duh!).

content.description: A hard mantle gets you up to a great stance. From here, it is a no hands dyno to the top.  Have fun.
content.protection: A pad, be careful if your foot blows on the dyno.
content.location: It is on the left side of the slab.

climbs.name: Bob's Ramp (submitted as Sorrowful Journey)
climbs.fa: Bob Horan, 1999, posted by Stephen Nance

content.description: A fun, but hard, dihedral start gets you up into some "decent holds", then up through the dihedral and out left to some fun ending holds.
content.location: This is on the back side of the boulder, it is obvious.

pathTokens: Chalk Creek Boulder aka Boulder of Sorrow
